awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: ORIGIN: Origin Inference from Geospatial Isotope Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Long-distance migration is a unique and important behavior with widespread implications for environmental and ecological systems. Animals face direct threats during migration ranging from severe nutritional stress to potential interactions with wind farms and other anthropogenic hazards. Migration links the geographic endpoints of an animal?s life cycle, and patterns of migration determine where and when animals are dependent on habitats that may be threatened or experiencing change due to human activities. Pathways of migration represent potential transmission paths for diseases, parasites, and nutrients carried by migrants. Despite the long-recognized significance of migration, detailed information on migration patterns for most animals is remarkably limited. The field of migration research is poised for major advances due to the development of new technologies and the potential to combine different types of data providing complementary information on animal migration. The ORIGIN project will represent a collaboration between biologists, geochemists, and computer scientists to develop software and database resources allowing researchers to take advantage of one particularly powerful method of reconstructing migration patterns ? the use of natural chemical signals preserved in the body tissues of migrants. In the course of this research the ORIGIN team will develop new statistical approaches that are widely useful to scientists and will provide novel interdisciplinary training to graduate students and research opportunities for undergraduates from STEM-underrepresented groups.

The goal of the ORIGIN project is to develop data and analytical resources that facilitate major advances in understanding of ecological, evolutionary, physiological, and biogeochemical dimensions of animal migration by increasing the use and standardization of isotope-enabled migration research methods. ORIGIN will consist of two integrated platforms that together provide the data resources, analytical tools, and project support necessary to streamline the analysis of data from migratory animal samples. First, updates to the IsoMAP web-GIS platform will enhance its ability to provide timely, authoritative, and comprehensive map data products and models describing patterns of isotopic variation in the environment. Second, these products will be used by a new package developed for the R programming environment that will provide an accessible but flexible suite of tools supporting 1) analysis of isotopic and non-isotopic data to evaluate the migratory origin of individuals, including two distinct Bayesian approaches for integration of data from multiple makers, 2) planning of isotope-enabled migration research projects, and 3) generation of analytics for assessment of statistical assignment results. ORIGIN will develop infrastructure that will support a wide range of scientific communities, and will support training and scientific outreach programs including a graduate short course in spatial sciences and human migration-focused research opportunities for undergraduates from STEM-underrepresented groups. Project results will be disseminated at http://isomap.org.

por.por_cntn:
Stable isotopic landscape (aka isoscape) modeling brings new insights into the study of a wide array of research questions in multiple disciplines. However, the adoption of isoscape modeling has been hindered by the obstacles individual researchers face in collecting, compiling, and integrating heterogeneous environmental and isotopic data over large spatial and temporal scales and in developing and interpreting geostatistical models. To help address these challenges, the ORIGIN project aims to develop data and analytical resources that facilitate major advances in understanding of ecological, evolutionary, physiological, and biogeochemical dimensions of animal migration by increasing the use and standardization of isotope-enabled migration research methods. ORIGIN consists of two integrated platforms that together provide the data resources, analytical tools, and project support necessary to streamline the analysis of data from migratory animal samples. First, the IsoMAP web GIS platform provides a science gateway for online isoscape modeling, analysis, and prediction.  The IsoMAP platform is updated to enhance its ability to provide timely, authoritative, and comprehensive map data products and models describing patterns of isotopic variation in the environment.  Second, these products may be used by a new package developed for the R programming environment, AssignR, which provides an accessible but flexible suite of tools supporting 1) analysis of isotopic and non-isotopic data to evaluate the migratory origin of individuals, including two distinct Bayesian approaches for integration of data from multiple makers, 2) planning of isotope-enabled migration research projects, and 3) generation of analytics for assessment of statistical assignment results. ORIGIN has been disseminated within and beyond the research community through publication, online distribution of software, and sponsorship of student training via the University of Utah SPATIAL short course.

Our award focuses on developing and updating the IsoMAP web-GIS platform to enhance its ability to provide timely, authoritative, and comprehensive map data products and models describing patterns of isotopic variation in the environment. IsoMAP accesses and integrates a large amount of diverse datasets and enable users to develop isoscape models over selected spatial and temporal domains using geostatistical algorithms, predict maps for the stable isotopic ratios of water and plants, and associate a sample?s isotope value with its most likely geographic origin. The main challenges in developing the IsoMAP gateway are efficiently processing a large number of heterogeneous geospatial datasets in response to user interactions with the web user interface and streamlining the data update process so that it is easy to keep the climate datasets up to date. To this end, we used the raster functions and materialized views of Postgres/PostGIS database to manage and process the diverse datasets (i.e., CRU, PRISM, ETOPO, and water isotope station data). This geospatial data acquisition and processing pipeline allows us to automate the data update process and keep the geospatial datasets up to date.

In addition to H and O isotope prediction, the IsoMAP web system is enhanced to provide preliminary Sr. isotope prediction capability. A static Sr. prediction map has been integrated into the system, allowing users to visualize the data and assign sample origins using the Sr. isoscape.

The IsoMAP system provides a set of REST APIs to enable other data analysis toolkits to discover, access, and reuse the isoscape data produced by the system. For example, advanced researchers who study the geographic assignment of animal samples may use the assignR package to calculate the posterior probabilities of origin. These users need to download isotope raster maps and use them as input to find out a linear relationship between known-origin tissue isotopes and the precipitation isotopes. The REST APIs enable users to search the isoscape models and download the predicted maps from the IsoMAP system. Existing IsoMAP gateway users can download data from their private jobs and public jobs after authentication using their portal credentials, while other users can only search or download public job results as anonymous users.

One journal paper titled "Streamlining geospatial data processing for isotopic landscape modeling" was published to the Concurrency and Computation Practice and Experience Journal at the end of project (http://doi.org/10.1002/cpe.6324). It describes the implementation of the improved IsoMAP web system. Two conference papers including a demo track paper were published at Gateways 2018 and Gateways 2020.

Up until now, there are around 2600 registered users who have run around 14,000 simulations using IsoMAP. By making it easier and faster to update, integrate and process a large amount of environmental data, create geostatistical models, and use it to predict isoscape distribution and assign probability based on animal samples, this project helps the broad research community make effective progress toward applying the isoscape modeling technique in solving complex real-world problems.
